Result: The experiments validate that integrating visual and audio cues enhances the generation of engaging and natural speech responses.

Conclusion: The study demonstrates the potential of multimodal inputs in improving conversational agents by enabling them to generate human-like speech.

Abstract: Human conversation involves language, speech, and visual cues, with each
medium providing complementary information. For instance, speech conveys a vibe
or tone not fully captured by text alone. While multimodal LLMs focus on
generating text responses from diverse inputs, less attention has been paid to
generating natural and engaging speech. We propose a human-like agent that
generates speech responses based on conversation mood and responsive style
information. To achieve this, we build a novel MultiSensory Conversation
dataset focused on speech to enable agents to generate natural speech. We then
propose a multimodal LLM-based model for generating text responses and voice
descriptions, which are used to generate speech covering paralinguistic
information. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of utilizing
both visual and audio modalities in conversation to generate engaging speech.
The source code is available in https://github.com/kimtaesu24/MSenC

</details>


### [346] [An Evaluation-Centric Paradigm for Scientific Visualization Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15160)
*Kuangshi Ai,Haichao Miao,Zhimin Li,Chaoli Wang,Shusen Liu*

Main category: cs.HC

TL;DR: The paper discusses the need for benchmarks to evaluate the capabilities of scientific visualization (SciVis) agents in translating user intentions into data visualizations, proposing a framework and collaboration for developing such benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a lack of comprehensive, large-scale benchmarks for assessing the real-world capabilities of multi-modal large language model (MLLM)-based visualization agents in SciVis, making it hard to evaluate progress and compare agents.

Method: The authors outline types of evaluation necessary for SciVis agents, identify challenges, provide a proof-of-concept evaluation, and propose a collaborative effort to create a SciVis evaluation benchmark.

Result: A proof-of-concept example is presented to demonstrate the need and feasibility of such benchmarks, and the potential benefits of agent self-improvement through robust evaluation.

Conclusion: Developing a SciVis agentic evaluation benchmark will not only enable better assessment of current capabilities but will also foster innovation and accelerate advancements in the SciVis field.

Abstract: Recent advances in multi-modal large language models (MLLMs) have enabled
increasingly sophisticated autonomous visualization agents capable of
translating user intentions into data visualizations. However, measuring
progress and comparing different agents remains challenging, particularly in
scientific visualization (SciVis), due to the absence of comprehensive,
large-scale benchmarks for evaluating real-world capabilities. This position
paper examines the various types of evaluation required for SciVis agents,
outlines the associated challenges, provides a simple proof-of-concept
evaluation example, and discusses how evaluation benchmarks can facilitate
agent self-improvement. We advocate for a broader collaboration to develop a
SciVis agentic evaluation benchmark that would not only assess existing
capabilities but also drive innovation and stimulate future development in the
field.

</details>


<div id='math.ST'></div>

# math.ST [[Back]](#toc)

### [347] [Consistent causal discovery with equal error variances: a least-squares perspective](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15197)
*Anamitra Chaudhuri,Yang Ni,Anirban Bhattacharya*

Main category: math.ST

TL;DR: The paper tackles causal structure recovery among variables in linear acyclic SEMs, proposing a property on squared errors and a Bayesian DAG selection method.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The motivation is to improve causal structure identification in linear SEMs, especially given that such structures are uniquely identifiable under certain independence and variance assumptions.

Method: The authors establish a minimization property of the expected squared error in predictions using the parent variables and utilize this to design a Bayesian DAG selection process.

Result: The proposed property and Bayesian DAG selection method ensure consistent recovery of the true causal structure.

Conclusion: The true DAG can be effectively identified by leveraging the established error minimization property and applying the Bayesian selection method.

Abstract: We consider the problem of recovering the true causal structure among a set
of variables, generated by a linear acyclic structural equation model (SEM)
with the error terms being independent and having equal variances. It is
well-known that the true underlying directed acyclic graph (DAG) encoding the
causal structure is uniquely identifiable under this assumption. In this work,
we establish that the sum of minimum expected squared errors for every
variable, while predicted by the best linear combination of its parent
variables, is minimised if and only if the causal structure is represented by
any supergraph of the true DAG. This property is further utilised to design a
Bayesian DAG selection method that recovers the true graph consistently.

</details>


<div id='cond-mat.stat-mech'></div>

# cond-mat.stat-mech [[Back]](#toc)

### [348] [Data coarse graining can improve model performance](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14498)
*Alex Nguyen,David J. Schwab,Vudtiwat Ngampruetikorn*

Main category: cond-mat.stat-mech

TL;DR: This paper explores how data pruning and lossy data augmentation can improve machine learning generalization using a ridge-regularized linear regression model to analyze data coarse-graining schemes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand the paradox where lossy data transformations, which lose information, can improve generalization in machine learning.

Method: The authors use a solvable high-dimensional linear regression model and analyze systematic data coarse-graining schemes inspired by statistical physics concepts.

Result: The study finds a nonmonotonic relationship between prediction risk and coarse-graining, where filtering out less relevant features ('high-pass') improves generalization, but removing important ones ('low-pass') harms performance.

Conclusion: Data coarse-graining can help isolate predictive signals, offering insights into how lossy data augmentation improves generalization by leveraging statistical physics principles.

Abstract: Lossy data transformations by definition lose information. Yet, in modern
machine learning, methods like data pruning and lossy data augmentation can
help improve generalization performance. We study this paradox using a solvable
model of high-dimensional, ridge-regularized linear regression under 'data
coarse graining.' Inspired by the renormalization group in statistical physics,
we analyze coarse-graining schemes that systematically discard features based
on their relevance to the learning task. Our results reveal a nonmonotonic
dependence of the prediction risk on the degree of coarse graining. A
'high-pass' scheme--which filters out less relevant, lower-signal features--can
help models generalize better. By contrast, a 'low-pass' scheme that integrates
out more relevant, higher-signal features is purely detrimental. Crucially,
using optimal regularization, we demonstrate that this nonmonotonicity is a
distinct effect of data coarse graining and not an artifact of double descent.
Our framework offers a clear, analytical explanation for why careful data
augmentation works: it strips away less relevant degrees of freedom and
isolates more predictive signals. Our results highlight a complex, nonmonotonic
risk landscape shaped by the structure of the data, and illustrate how ideas
from statistical physics provide a principled lens for understanding modern
machine learning phenomena.

</details>


<div id='eess.IV'></div>

# eess.IV [[Back]](#toc)

### [349] [Learning Mechanistic Subtypes of Neurodegeneration with a Physics-Informed Variational Autoencoder Mixture Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15124)
*Sanduni Pinnawala,Annabelle Hartanto,Ivor J. A. Simpson,Peter A. Wijeratne*

Main category: eess.IV

TL;DR: The paper introduces a deep generative model that merges physics-guided PDEs with variational autoencoder mixtures to analyze neurodegenerative disease mechanisms and subtypes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address limitations in current physics-based machine learning methods that rely on single PDEs, which fail to account for spatially varying dynamics and heterogeneous mechanisms in diseases.

Method: Combines reaction-diffusion PDEs with variational autoencoder mixtures to create a model capable of inferring latent variables for disease subtype characterization.

Result: The model is tested on synthetic benchmarks and applied to Alzheimer's PET data, showing its ability to uncover mechanistic subtypes and interpret latent dynamic variables.

Conclusion: The approach advances the utility of machine learning in neurodegenerative disease modelling by integrating multiple PDE-driven mechanisms in a scalable, interpretable framework.

Abstract: Modelling the underlying mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases demands
methods that capture heterogeneous and spatially varying dynamics from sparse,
high-dimensional neuroimaging data. Integrating partial differential equation
(PDE) based physics knowledge with machine learning provides enhanced
interpretability and utility over classic numerical methods. However, current
physics-integrated machine learning methods are limited to considering a single
PDE, severely limiting their application to diseases where multiple mechanisms
are responsible for different groups (i.e., subtypes) and aggravating problems
with model misspecification and degeneracy. Here, we present a deep generative
model for learning mixtures of latent dynamic models governed by physics-based
PDEs, going beyond traditional approaches that assume a single PDE structure.
Our method integrates reaction-diffusion PDEs within a variational autoencoder
(VAE) mixture model framework, supporting inference of subtypes of
interpretable latent variables (e.g. diffusivity and reaction rates) from
neuroimaging data. We evaluate our method on synthetic benchmarks and
demonstrate its potential for uncovering mechanistic subtypes of Alzheimer's
disease progression from positron emission tomography (PET) data.

</details>


### [350] [Undersampled Phase Retrieval with Image Priors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15026)
*Stanislas Ducotterd,Zhiyuan Hu,Michael Unser,Jonathan Dong*

Main category: eess.IV

TL;DR: This paper aims to enhance phase retrieval by integrating image priors in the recovery process under severe undersampling conditions, significantly improving reconstruction success.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper is motivated by the challenge of recovering a complex signal from amplitude-only measurements, especially in conditions with severe undersampling. Current approaches neglect signal priors, which may lead to suboptimal recoveries.

Method: The study evaluates various image priors using structured random Fourier measurements to improve phase retrieval in cases of severe undersampling.

Result: The integration of image priors significantly boosts reconstruction quality, enabling accurate signal recovery even below the weak recovery threshold for phase retrieval.

Conclusion: Incorporating image priors into phase retrieval methods enhances recovery capabilities and accuracy, addressing key limitations of conventional approaches.

Abstract: Phase retrieval seeks to recover a complex signal from amplitude-only
measurements, a challenging nonlinear inverse problem. Current theory and
algorithms often ignore signal priors. By contrast, we evaluate here a variety
of image priors in the context of severe undersampling with structured random
Fourier measurements. Our results show that those priors significantly improve
reconstruction, allowing accurate reconstruction even below the weak recovery
threshold.

</details>


<div id='cs.SD'></div>

# cs.SD [[Back]](#toc)

### [351] [Deploying UDM Series in Real-Life Stuttered Speech Applications: A Clinical Evaluation Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14304)
*Eric Zhang,Li Wei,Sarah Chen,Michael Wang*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: This paper introduces the Unconstrained Dysfluency Modeling (UDM) framework, combining strong performance in automatic speech disorder detection with clinician-friendly interpretability and utility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To resolve the trade-off between high accuracy and clinical interpretability in stuttered and dysfluent speech detection systems, enabling practical adoption in clinical practice.

Method: The UDM framework uses a modular architecture, explicit phoneme alignment, and interpretable outputs. Extensive experiments were conducted with patients and speech-language pathologists to validate its performance.

Result: UDM achieved state-of-the-art performance with an F1 score of 0.89±0.04, interpretability scores of 4.2/5.0, 87% clinician acceptance, and reduced diagnostic time by 34%.

Conclusion: The Unconstrained Dysfluency Modeling framework is a promising solution for AI-assisted speech therapy, balancing accuracy, interpretability, and real-world clinical utility.

Abstract: Stuttered and dysfluent speech detection systems have traditionally suffered
from the trade-off between accuracy and clinical interpretability. While
end-to-end deep learning models achieve high performance, their black-box
nature limits clinical adoption. This paper looks at the Unconstrained
Dysfluency Modeling (UDM) series-the current state-of-the-art framework
developed by Berkeley that combines modular architecture, explicit phoneme
alignment, and interpretable outputs for real-world clinical deployment.
Through extensive experiments involving patients and certified speech-language
pathologists (SLPs), we demonstrate that UDM achieves state-of-the-art
performance (F1: 0.89+-0.04) while providing clinically meaningful
interpretability scores (4.2/5.0). Our deployment study shows 87% clinician
acceptance rate and 34% reduction in diagnostic time. The results provide
strong evidence that UDM represents a practical pathway toward AI-assisted
speech therapy in clinical environments.

</details>


### [352] [Two Web Toolkits for Multimodal Piano Performance Dataset Acquisition and Fingering Annotation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15222)
*Junhyung Park,Yonghyun Kim,Joonhyung Bae,Kirak Kim,Taegyun Kwon,Alexander Lerch,Juhan Nam*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces a web toolkit with two GUIs—PiaRec and ASDF—to simplify data collection and annotation for multimodal piano performance studies.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The motivation is to address the bottleneck caused by the laborious process of obtaining large-scale multimodal data in piano performance research.

Method: The authors designed a web toolkit comprising two GUIs: PiaRec for synchronized acquisition of various performance data (audio, video, MIDI, metadata) and ASDF for efficient annotation of performer fingering from visual data.

Result: This toolkit facilitates streamlined capture and annotation of multimodal piano datasets, making data acquisition and analysis more efficient.

Conclusion: The toolkit has the potential to advance multimodal piano performance research by significantly reducing barriers in data acquisition and annotation.

Abstract: Piano performance is a multimodal activity that intrinsically combines
physical actions with the acoustic rendition. Despite growing research interest
in analyzing the multimodal nature of piano performance, the laborious process
of acquiring large-scale multimodal data remains a significant bottleneck,
hindering further progress in this field. To overcome this barrier, we present
an integrated web toolkit comprising two graphical user interfaces (GUIs): (i)
PiaRec, which supports the synchronized acquisition of audio, video, MIDI, and
performance metadata. (ii) ASDF, which enables the efficient annotation of
performer fingering from the visual data. Collectively, this system can
streamline the acquisition of multimodal piano performance datasets.

</details>


### [353] [Spatial Audio Motion Understanding and Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14666)
*Arvind Krishna Sridhar,Yinyi Guo,Erik Visser*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces a framework for spatial audio reasoning focusing on moving sources, using spatial audio encoders, grounding models, structured attribute extraction, and a new benchmark dataset to evaluate performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable machines to interpret and reason about auditory scenes by understanding events and their spatial attributes, particularly moving sound sources, which remains a challenging task.

Method: The framework involves a spatial audio encoder to detect and estimate spatial attributes of overlapping events, an audio grounding model for generalization to unseen events, and the conditioning of a large language model on extracted structured spatial attributes. A new benchmark dataset is also introduced.

Result: The proposed approach shows improved performance in spatial audio reasoning tasks compared to a baseline model, particularly in understanding and reasoning about dynamic audio scenes with moving sources.

Conclusion: The framework demonstrates the viability of combining spatial audio processing, semantic alignment, and language models, along with a new benchmark, to improve spatial audio reasoning for complex auditory scenes.

Abstract: Spatial audio reasoning enables machines to interpret auditory scenes by
understanding events and their spatial attributes. In this work, we focus on
spatial audio understanding with an emphasis on reasoning about moving sources.
First, we introduce a spatial audio encoder that processes spatial audio to
detect multiple overlapping events and estimate their spatial attributes,
Direction of Arrival (DoA) and source distance, at the frame level. To
generalize to unseen events, we incorporate an audio grounding model that
aligns audio features with semantic audio class text embeddings via a
cross-attention mechanism. Second, to answer complex queries about dynamic
audio scenes involving moving sources, we condition a large language model
(LLM) on structured spatial attributes extracted by our model. Finally, we
introduce a spatial audio motion understanding and reasoning benchmark dataset
and demonstrate our framework's performance against the baseline model.

</details>


### [354] [MeanFlowSE: one-step generative speech enhancement via conditional mean flow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14858)
*Duojia Li,Shenghui Lu,Hongchen Pan,Zongyi Zhan,Qingyang Hong,Lin Li*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces MeanFlowSE, a generative speech enhancement model using single-step inference for real-time efficiency, outperforming multistep-based methods in computational cost and quality on VoiceBank-DEMAND.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Motivated by the inefficiency of multistep iterative solvers in generative speech enhancement models, the paper aims to develop a system that can achieve real-time performance while maintaining high-quality results.

Method: The model, MeanFlowSE, is trained to learn the average velocity over finite intervals using the MeanFlow identity and Jacobian-vector product (JVP), allowing single-step backward-in-time displacement for inference. It offers optional few-step refinement and eliminates external teacher or knowledge distillation requirements.

Result: MeanFlowSE demonstrates strong performance on VoiceBank-DEMAND in intelligibility, fidelity, and perceptual quality, achieving real-time efficiency with substantially reduced computational cost compared to multistep systems.

Conclusion: The proposed approach offers an efficient, high-fidelity single-step framework for real-time generative speech enhancement, demonstrating its practicality and performance advantages over traditional multistep methods.

Abstract: Multistep inference is a bottleneck for real-time generative speech
enhancement because flow- and diffusion-based systems learn an instantaneous
velocity field and therefore rely on iterative ordinary differential equation
(ODE) solvers. We introduce MeanFlowSE, a conditional generative model that
learns the average velocity over finite intervals along a trajectory. Using a
Jacobian-vector product (JVP) to instantiate the MeanFlow identity, we derive a
local training objective that directly supervises finite-interval displacement
while remaining consistent with the instantaneous-field constraint on the
diagonal. At inference, MeanFlowSE performs single-step generation via a
backward-in-time displacement, removing the need for multistep solvers; an
optional few-step variant offers additional refinement. On VoiceBank-DEMAND,
the single-step model achieves strong intelligibility, fidelity, and perceptual
quality with substantially lower computational cost than multistep baselines.
The method requires no knowledge distillation or external teachers, providing
an efficient, high-fidelity framework for real-time generative speech
enhancement.

</details>


### [355] [FCPE: A Fast Context-based Pitch Estimation Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15140)
*Yuxin Luo,Ruoyi Zhang,Lu-Chuan Liu,Tianyu Li,Hangyu Liu*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces FCPE, a noise-tolerant, efficient pitch estimation model for monophonic audio, achieving state-of-the-art results.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing pitch estimation methods for tasks like MIDI transcription and singing voice conversion perform poorly in noisy conditions.

Method: The authors propose FCPE, a model based on the Lynx-Net architecture with depth-wise separable convolutions, designed to capture mel spectrogram features efficiently and robustly.

Result: FCPE achieves 96.79% Raw Pitch Accuracy on the MIR-1K dataset and boasts a real-time factor of 0.0062 on an RTX 4090 GPU, excelling in both accuracy and speed.

Conclusion: FCPE is a promising, efficient, and robust solution for pitch estimation under noisy conditions, matching state-of-the-art accuracy while being computationally efficient.

Abstract: Pitch estimation (PE) in monophonic audio is crucial for MIDI transcription
and singing voice conversion (SVC), but existing methods suffer significant
performance degradation under noise. In this paper, we propose FCPE, a fast
context-based pitch estimation model that employs a Lynx-Net architecture with
depth-wise separable convolutions to effectively capture mel spectrogram
features while maintaining low computational cost and robust noise tolerance.
Experiments show that our method achieves 96.79\% Raw Pitch Accuracy (RPA) on
the MIR-1K dataset, on par with the state-of-the-art methods. The Real-Time
Factor (RTF) is 0.0062 on a single RTX 4090 GPU, which significantly
outperforms existing algorithms in efficiency. Code is available at
https://github.com/CNChTu/FCPE.

</details>


### [356] [Back to Ear: Perceptually Driven High Fidelity Music Reconstruction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14912)
*Kangdi Wang,Zhiyue Wu,Dinghao Zhou,Rui Lin,Junyu Dai,Tao Jiang*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces an improved Variational Autoencoder (VAE) for audio signal reconstruction, addressing perceptual shortcomings in open-source models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing audio-focused VAEs fail to adequately account for perceptual auditory aspects, impacting phase accuracy and spatial quality during signal reconstruction.

Method: The authors propose {
abla}ar-VAE with key innovations: (i) perceptual filtering via K-weighting for loss alignment, (ii) novel stereo coherence and phase precision losses, and (iii) spectral supervision for magnitude and phase components.

Result: Experiments demonstrate that {
abla}ar-VAE significantly outperforms open-source alternatives, particularly for high-frequency harmonics and spatial audio reconstruction.

Conclusion: {
abla}ar-VAE optimizes VAE training for auditory quality, enabling more precise and perceptually aligned audio signal reconstruction.

Abstract: Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) are essential for large-scale audio tasks
like diffusion-based generation. However, existing open-source models often
neglect auditory perceptual aspects during training, leading to weaknesses in
phase accuracy and stereophonic spatial representation. To address these
challenges, we propose {\epsilon}ar-VAE, an open-source music signal
reconstruction model that rethinks and optimizes the VAE training paradigm. Our
contributions are threefold: (i) A K-weighting perceptual filter applied prior
to loss calculation to align the objective with auditory perception. (ii) Two
novel phase losses: a Correlation Loss for stereo coherence, and a Phase Loss
using its derivatives--Instantaneous Frequency and Group Delay--for precision.
(iii) A new spectral supervision paradigm where magnitude is supervised by all
four Mid/Side/Left/Right components, while phase is supervised only by the LR
components. Experiments show {\epsilon}ar-VAE at 44.1kHz substantially
outperforms leading open-source models across diverse metrics, showing
particular strength in reconstructing high-frequency harmonics and the spatial
characteristics.

</details>


### [357] [Estimating Respiratory Effort from Nocturnal Breathing Sounds for Obstructive Sleep Apnoea Screening](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14944)
*Xiaolei Xu,Chaoyue Niu,Guy J. Brown,Hector Romero,Ning Ma*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: This study proposes using nocturnal audio, rather than additional sensors, to estimate respiratory effort and detect obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA), improving scalability and patient comfort.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Many patients with OSA remain undiagnosed due to the cost and complexity of traditional diagnosis methods like polysomnography. Acoustic screenings are limited by noise and lack of physiological signals.

Method: A latent-space fusion framework was developed to estimate respiratory effort from audio recordings, embedding these signals with acoustic features for OSA event detection.

Result: Respiratory effort estimation achieved a concordance correlation coefficient of 0.48, and combining effort with audio enhanced sensitivity and AUC metrics for OSA detection, especially at low thresholds.

Conclusion: The proposed audio-based method enables scalable, sensor-free, and long-term monitoring of OSA, relying solely on smartphone recordings.

Abstract: Obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) is a prevalent condition with significant
health consequences, yet many patients remain undiagnosed due to the complexity
and cost of over-night polysomnography. Acoustic-based screening provides a
scalable alternative, yet performance is limited by environmental noise and the
lack of physiological context. Respiratory effort is a key signal used in
clinical scoring of OSA events, but current approaches require additional
contact sensors that reduce scalability and patient comfort. This paper
presents the first study to estimate respiratory effort directly from nocturnal
audio, enabling physiological context to be recovered from sound alone. We
propose a latent-space fusion framework that integrates the estimated effort
embeddings with acoustic features for OSA detection. Using a dataset of 157
nights from 103 participants recorded in home environments, our respiratory
effort estimator achieves a concordance correlation coefficient of 0.48,
capturing meaningful respiratory dynamics. Fusing effort and audio improves
sensitivity and AUC over audio-only baselines, especially at low
apnoea-hypopnoea index thresholds. The proposed approach requires only
smartphone audio at test time, which enables sensor-free, scalable, and
longitudinal OSA monitoring.

</details>


### [358] [Exploring How Audio Effects Alter Emotion with Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15151)
*Stelios Katsis,Vassilis Lyberatos,Spyridon Kantarelis,Edmund Dervakos,Giorgos Stamou*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper explores how foundation models can analyze the emotional effects of audio effects (FX) like reverberation and distortion, highlighting their impact on affective perception during music listening.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the gap in research on the systematic impact of audio effects on emotional responses, using large-scale neural architectures as tools.

Method: The study uses probing methods on embeddings generated by foundation models pretrained on multimodal data to analyze nonlinear relationships between audio FX and emotion.

Result: The research uncovers patterns tying specific audio FX to emotional outcomes and assesses the robustness of foundation audio models.

Conclusion: The study enhances understanding of the emotional role of sound design in music, with relevance to fields like music cognition and affective computing.

Abstract: Audio effects (FX) such as reverberation, distortion, modulation, and dynamic
range processing play a pivotal role in shaping emotional responses during
music listening. While prior studies have examined links between low-level
audio features and affective perception, the systematic impact of audio FX on
emotion remains underexplored. This work investigates how foundation models -
large-scale neural architectures pretrained on multimodal data - can be
leveraged to analyze these effects. Such models encode rich associations
between musical structure, timbre, and affective meaning, offering a powerful
framework for probing the emotional consequences of sound design techniques. By
applying various probing methods to embeddings from deep learning models, we
examine the complex, nonlinear relationships between audio FX and estimated
emotion, uncovering patterns tied to specific effects and evaluating the
robustness of foundation audio models. Our findings aim to advance
understanding of the perceptual impact of audio production practices, with
implications for music cognition, performance, and affective computing.

</details>


### [359] [Explicit Context-Driven Neural Acoustic Modeling for High-Fidelity RIR Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15210)
*Chen Si,Qianyi Wu,Chaitanya Amballa,Romit Roy Choudhury*

Main category: cs.SD

TL;DR: The paper introduces MiNAF, a method for realistic sound simulation using explicit geometric features to improve room impulse response (RIR) prediction.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enhance the accuracy of room impulse response (RIR) predictions in applications requiring realistic sound simulations, while addressing limitations of current methods that underutilize geometric information.

Method: MiNAF uses a rough room mesh to extract local geometric context as explicit distance distributions, which inform a neural implicit model to better predict RIRs.

Result: MiNAF demonstrates competitive performance compared to traditional and state-of-the-art methods across evaluation metrics, including with limited training data.

Conclusion: Embedding explicit geometric features into neural models significantly improves RIR prediction, enhancing high-fidelity sound simulations in diverse scenarios.

Abstract: Realistic sound simulation plays a critical role in many applications. A key
element in sound simulation is the room impulse response (RIR), which
characterizes how sound propagates from a source to a listener within a given
space. Recent studies have applied neural implicit methods to learn RIR using
context information collected from the environment, such as scene images.
However, these approaches do not effectively leverage explicit geometric
information from the environment. To further exploit the potential of neural
implicit models with direct geometric features, we present Mesh-infused Neural
Acoustic Field (MiNAF), which queries a rough room mesh at given locations and
extracts distance distributions as an explicit representation of local context.
Our approach demonstrates that incorporating explicit local geometric features
can better guide the neural network in generating more accurate RIR
predictions. Through comparisons with conventional and state-of-the-art
baseline methods, we show that MiNAF performs competitively across various
evaluation metrics. Furthermore, we verify the robustness of MiNAF in datasets
with limited training samples, demonstrating an advance in high-fidelity sound
simulation.

</details>


<div id='cs.DB'></div>

# cs.DB [[Back]](#toc)

### [360] [A Systematic Review of FAIR-compliant Big Data Software Reference Architectures](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14370)
*João Pedro de Carvalho Castro,Maria Júlia Soares De Grandi,Cristina Dutra de Aguiar*

Main category: cs.DB

TL;DR: This paper reviews architectural solutions for repositories that align with FAIR principles, analyzing 323 references and identifying key studies on big data and FAIR-compliant systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper is motivated by the challenges of managing diverse and rapidly-generated research data while striving to adhere to the FAIR Principles, crucial for the Open Science movement.

Method: The authors conducted a systematic review of 323 references, focusing on software reference architectures related to FAIR principles and assessing their features, limitations, and research gaps.

Result: The study identified 7 general-purpose big data SRAs, 13 FAIR implementation pipelines, and 3 FAIR-compliant big data SRAs, including their characteristics and areas for improvement.

Conclusion: The paper concludes with an analysis of current solutions, acknowledging limitations and providing insights for future research opportunities in FAIR-compliant repository architectures.

Abstract: To meet the standards of the Open Science movement, the FAIR Principles
emphasize the importance of making scientific data Findable, Accessible,
Interoperable, and Reusable. Yet, creating a repository that adheres to these
principles presents significant challenges. Managing large volumes of diverse
research data and metadata, often generated rapidly, requires a precise
approach. This necessity has led to the development of Software Reference
Architectures (SRAs) to guide the implementation process for FAIR-compliant
repositories. This article conducts a systematic review of research efforts
focused on architectural solutions for such repositories. We detail our
methodology, covering all activities undertaken in the planning and execution
phases of the review. We analyze 323 references from reputable sources and
expert recommendations, identifying 7 studies on general-purpose big data SRAs,
13 pipelines implementing FAIR Principles in specific contexts, and 3
FAIR-compliant big data SRAs. We provide a thorough description of their key
features and assess whether the research questions posed in the planning phase
were adequately addressed. Additionally, we discuss the limitations of the
retrieved studies and identify tendencies and opportunities for further
research.

</details>


### [361] [A Case for Computing on Unstructured Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14601)
*Mushtari Sadia,Amrita Roy Chowdhury,Ang Chen*

Main category: cs.DB

TL;DR: The paper advocates for a new framework for handling unstructured data by extracting latent structure, processing it, and projecting it back to retain its accessibility while enabling structured computation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unstructured data dominates information landscapes, yet current systems fail to adequately support it. A new paradigm is needed to bridge the gap between structured analytic power and unstructured data richness.

Method: The authors propose a bi-directional three-stage pipeline: extracting latent structure from unstructured data, applying processing techniques to the structure, and projecting it back to its original unstructured form.

Result: The paper introduces MXFlow, a novel data system that illustrates this paradigm with two use cases, highlighting its potential for unlocking computational and analytical capabilities.

Conclusion: MXFlow showcases how unstructured data can leverage structured computation while maintaining its inherent richness and usability for both humans and AI, making this paradigm a promising direction for future systems.

Abstract: Unstructured data, such as text, images, audio, and video, comprises the vast
majority of the world's information, yet it remains poorly supported by
traditional data systems that rely on structured formats for computation. We
argue for a new paradigm, which we call computing on unstructured data, built
around three stages: extraction of latent structure, transformation of this
structure through data processing techniques, and projection back into
unstructured formats. This bi-directional pipeline allows unstructured data to
benefit from the analytical power of structured computation, while preserving
the richness and accessibility of unstructured representations for human and AI
consumption. We illustrate this paradigm through two use cases and present the
research components that need to be developed in a new data system called
MXFlow.

</details>


<div id='cs.CR'></div>

# cs.CR [[Back]](#toc)

### [362] [Beyond Classification: Evaluating LLMs for Fine-Grained Automatic Malware Behavior Auditing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14335)
*Xinran Zheng,Xingzhi Qian,Yiling He,Shuo Yang,Lorenzo Cavallaro*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: MalEval is a new framework designed to assess the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) in auditing Android malware behaviors by addressing challenges like scarce annotations, noise from benign code, and unverifiable outputs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing malware classification tools lack the ability to provide causal and verifiable explanations of malicious behaviors, a critical need for substantiating claims about such activities amidst the complexity of adversarial intent.

Method: MalEval introduces expert-verified reports, enhanced API lists, and function-level structural representations. It defines four specific auditing tasks and evaluates LLM-based performance on a curated dataset using domain-specific metrics.

Result: The study showed that while LLMs have potential in malware auditing tasks, they also exhibit critical limitations, which MalEval helps to systematically benchmark for reproducibility and further research.

Conclusion: MalEval serves as both a benchmark and a foundation for advancing LLM-aided malware auditing, addressing real-world challenges and helping develop more reliable systems for understanding malware behaviors.

Abstract: Automated malware classification has achieved strong detection performance.
Yet, malware behavior auditing seeks causal and verifiable explanations of
malicious activities -- essential not only to reveal what malware does but also
to substantiate such claims with evidence. This task is challenging, as
adversarial intent is often hidden within complex, framework-heavy
applications, making manual auditing slow and costly. Large Language Models
(LLMs) could help address this gap, but their auditing potential remains
largely unexplored due to three limitations: (1) scarce fine-grained
annotations for fair assessment; (2) abundant benign code obscuring malicious
signals; and (3) unverifiable, hallucination-prone outputs undermining
attribution credibility. To close this gap, we introduce MalEval, a
comprehensive framework for fine-grained Android malware auditing, designed to
evaluate how effectively LLMs support auditing under real-world constraints.
MalEval provides expert-verified reports and an updated sensitive API list to
mitigate ground truth scarcity and reduce noise via static reachability
analysis. Function-level structural representations serve as intermediate
attribution units for verifiable evaluation. Building on this, we define four
analyst-aligned tasks -- function prioritization, evidence attribution,
behavior synthesis, and sample discrimination -- together with domain-specific
metrics and a unified workload-oriented score. We evaluate seven widely used
LLMs on a curated dataset of recent malware and misclassified benign apps,
offering the first systematic assessment of their auditing capabilities.
MalEval reveals both promising potential and critical limitations across audit
stages, providing a reproducible benchmark and foundation for future research
on LLM-enhanced malware behavior auditing. MalEval is publicly available at
https://github.com/ZhengXR930/MalEval.git

</details>


### [363] [FedMentor: Domain-Aware Differential Privacy for Heterogeneous Federated LLMs in Mental Health](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14275)
*Nobin Sarwar,Shubhashis Roy Dipta*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: FedMentor is a federated learning framework that combines LoRA and domain-aware Differential Privacy to enable privacy-preserving fine-tuning of large language models in sensitive domains, like mental health.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper aims to address the challenge of adapting large language models for sensitive applications such as healthcare, where strict confidentiality needs to be balanced with model utility and safety.

Method: FedMentor employs federated fine-tuning by integrating Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and domain-aware Differential Privacy. Each client tailors privacy noise scales according to its data sensitivity, while the server adaptively adjusts noise levels based on utility thresholds.

Result: In experiments on mental health datasets, FedMentor improved safety (e.g., raising safe output rates and reducing toxicity) while maintaining performance metrics like BERTScore F1 and ROUGE-L within 0.5% of non-private baselines. It also supports scalability with large models on limited hardware resources.

Conclusion: FedMentor offers a feasible and scalable solution for privately fine-tuning large language models, enabling safer applications in sensitive fields like healthcare.

Abstract: Privacy-preserving adaptation of Large Language Models (LLMs) in sensitive
domains (e.g., mental health) requires balancing strict confidentiality with
model utility and safety. We propose FedMentor, a federated fine-tuning
framework that integrates Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and domain-aware
Differential Privacy (DP) to meet per-domain privacy budgets while maintaining
performance. Each client (domain) applies a custom DP noise scale proportional
to its data sensitivity, and the server adaptively reduces noise when utility
falls below a threshold. In experiments on three mental health datasets, we
show that FedMentor improves safety over standard Federated Learning without
privacy, raising safe output rates by up to three points and lowering toxicity,
while maintaining utility (BERTScore F1 and ROUGE-L) within 0.5% of the
non-private baseline and close to the centralized upper bound. The framework
scales to backbones with up to 1.7B parameters on single-GPU clients, requiring
< 173 MB of communication per round. FedMentor demonstrates a practical
approach to privately fine-tune LLMs for safer deployments in healthcare and
other sensitive fields.

</details>


### [364] [Beyond Data Privacy: New Privacy Risks for Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14278)
*Yuntao Du,Zitao Li,Ninghui Li,Bolin Ding*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper addresses privacy risks from deploying large language models (LLMs), highlighting vulnerabilities for data leakage and advanced attacks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The authors aim to address the underexplored privacy threats posed by the deployment and usage of LLMs, beyond their training phase.

Method: The paper systematically examines emerging privacy risks associated with LLMs and discusses mitigation strategies.

Result: Findings reveal vulnerabilities in LLM-powered systems that adversaries can exploit for privacy attacks, emphasizing the impact on individual, financial, and societal aspects.

Conclusion: The research calls for prioritizing defense mechanisms against evolving privacy threats in LLM usage, urging the research community to expand focus beyond data training risks.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable progress in natural
language understanding, reasoning, and autonomous decision-making. However,
these advancements have also come with significant privacy concerns. While
significant research has focused on mitigating the data privacy risks of LLMs
during various stages of model training, less attention has been paid to new
threats emerging from their deployment. The integration of LLMs into widely
used applications and the weaponization of their autonomous abilities have
created new privacy vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities provide
opportunities for both inadvertent data leakage and malicious exfiltration from
LLM-powered systems. Additionally, adversaries can exploit these systems to
launch sophisticated, large-scale privacy attacks, threatening not only
individual privacy but also financial security and societal trust. In this
paper, we systematically examine these emerging privacy risks of LLMs. We also
discuss potential mitigation strategies and call for the research community to
broaden its focus beyond data privacy risks, developing new defenses to address
the evolving threats posed by increasingly powerful LLMs and LLM-powered
systems.

</details>


### [365] [The Sum Leaks More Than Its Parts: Compositional Privacy Risks and Mitigations in Multi-Agent Collaboration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14284)
*Vaidehi Patil,Elias Stengel-Eskin,Mohit Bansal*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: This paper introduces compositional privacy leakage in multi-agent LLM systems, highlighting privacy risks that arise from cumulative interactions and proposing two defense strategies to mitigate these risks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper seeks to address emerging privacy risks in multi-agent systems using large language models, where sensitive information can be inferred cumulatively across multiple interactions.

Method: The authors develop a framework to model how combined agent interactions and auxiliary knowledge amplify privacy risks. They introduce two strategies: Theory-of-Mind defense (ToM) to assess intents and Collaborative Consensus Defense (CoDef) for responder collaboration.

Result: Experiments showed ToM defense blocks up to 97% sensitive queries but harms benign utility, whereas CoDef achieves the best balance with a 79.8% balanced outcome.

Conclusion: These findings expose compositional privacy leakage risks in LLM systems and suggest actionable defense mechanisms like ToM and CoDef for protecting sensitive information.

Abstract: As large language models (LLMs) become integral to multi-agent systems, new
privacy risks emerge that extend beyond memorization, direct inference, or
single-turn evaluations. In particular, seemingly innocuous responses, when
composed across interactions, can cumulatively enable adversaries to recover
sensitive information, a phenomenon we term compositional privacy leakage. We
present the first systematic study of such compositional privacy leaks and
possible mitigation methods in multi-agent LLM systems. First, we develop a
framework that models how auxiliary knowledge and agent interactions jointly
amplify privacy risks, even when each response is benign in isolation. Next, to
mitigate this, we propose and evaluate two defense strategies: (1)
Theory-of-Mind defense (ToM), where defender agents infer a questioner's intent
by anticipating how their outputs may be exploited by adversaries, and (2)
Collaborative Consensus Defense (CoDef), where responder agents collaborate
with peers who vote based on a shared aggregated state to restrict sensitive
information spread. Crucially, we balance our evaluation across compositions
that expose sensitive information and compositions that yield benign
inferences. Our experiments quantify how these defense strategies differ in
balancing the privacy-utility trade-off. We find that while chain-of-thought
alone offers limited protection to leakage (~39% sensitive blocking rate), our
ToM defense substantially improves sensitive query blocking (up to 97%) but can
reduce benign task success. CoDef achieves the best balance, yielding the
highest Balanced Outcome (79.8%), highlighting the benefit of combining
explicit reasoning with defender collaboration. Together, our results expose a
new class of risks in collaborative LLM deployments and provide actionable
insights for designing safeguards against compositional, context-driven privacy
leakage.

</details>


### [366] [LLM Jailbreak Detection for (Almost) Free!](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14558)
*Guorui Chen,Yifan Xia,Xiaojun Jia,Zhijiang Li,Philip Torr,Jindong Gu*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper introduces a Free Jailbreak Detection (FJD) method that identifies jailbreak prompts in large language models (LLMs) by analyzing differences in output distributions with minimal computational costs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The motivation is to enhance security in widely used LLMs by addressing their susceptibility to jailbreak attacks without increasing computational overhead.

Method: The proposed FJD approach leverages affirmative instructions and temperature-scaled logits to differentiate between jailbreak and benign prompts. Virtual instruction learning is applied to further improve detection accuracy.

Result: Experiments demonstrate that FJD effectively identifies jailbreak prompts in aligned LLMs with negligible additional computational costs.

Conclusion: FJD is a computationally efficient and effective method for improving the security of LLMs against jailbreak attacks.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) enhance security through alignment when widely
used, but remain susceptible to jailbreak attacks capable of producing
inappropriate content. Jailbreak detection methods show promise in mitigating
jailbreak attacks through the assistance of other models or multiple model
inferences. However, existing methods entail significant computational costs.
In this paper, we first present a finding that the difference in output
distributions between jailbreak and benign prompts can be employed for
detecting jailbreak prompts. Based on this finding, we propose a Free Jailbreak
Detection (FJD) which prepends an affirmative instruction to the input and
scales the logits by temperature to further distinguish between jailbreak and
benign prompts through the confidence of the first token. Furthermore, we
enhance the detection performance of FJD through the integration of virtual
instruction learning. Extensive experiments on aligned LLMs show that our FJD
can effectively detect jailbreak prompts with almost no additional
computational costs during LLM inference.

</details>


### [367] [ATLANTIS: AI-driven Threat Localization, Analysis, and Triage Intelligence System](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14589)
*Taesoo Kim,HyungSeok Han,Soyeon Park,Dae R. Jeong,Dohyeok Kim,Dongkwan Kim,Eunsoo Kim,Jiho Kim,Joshua Wang,Kangsu Kim,Sangwoo Ji,Woosun Song,Hanqing Zhao,Andrew Chin,Gyejin Lee,Kevin Stevens,Mansour Alharthi,Yizhuo Zhai,Cen Zhang,Joonun Jang,Yeongjin Jang,Ammar Askar,Dongju Kim,Fabian Fleischer,Jeongin Cho,Junsik Kim,Kyungjoon Ko,Insu Yun,Sangdon Park,Dowoo Baik,Haein Lee,Hyeon Heo,Minjae Gwon,Minjae Lee,Minwoo Baek,Seunggi Min,Wonyoung Kim,Yonghwi Jin,Younggi Park,Yunjae Choi,Jinho Jung,Gwanhyun Lee,Junyoung Jang,Kyuheon Kim,Yeonghyeon Cha,Youngjoon Kim*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: ATLANTIS is a cyber reasoning system built to autonomously discover and fix software vulnerabilities, winning DARPA's AIxCC competition.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper aims to address limitations in automated vulnerability discovery and program repair, especially at the speed and scale required by modern software environments.

Method: The system integrates large language models with program analysis techniques like symbolic execution, directed fuzzing, and static analysis to ensure precision and scalability.

Result: ATLANTIS successfully demonstrated its capabilities in diverse codebases and provided semantically correct patches, earning first place in the AIxCC competition.

Conclusion: ATLANTIS highlights the potential of combining AI-driven approaches with traditional program analysis to improve cybersecurity at scale, and its artifacts are shared for advancing future research.

Abstract: We present ATLANTIS, the cyber reasoning system developed by Team Atlanta
that won 1st place in the Final Competition of DARPA's AI Cyber Challenge
(AIxCC) at DEF CON 33 (August 2025). AIxCC (2023-2025) challenged teams to
build autonomous cyber reasoning systems capable of discovering and patching
vulnerabilities at the speed and scale of modern software. ATLANTIS integrates
large language models (LLMs) with program analysis -- combining symbolic
execution, directed fuzzing, and static analysis -- to address limitations in
automated vulnerability discovery and program repair. Developed by researchers
at Georgia Institute of Technology, Samsung Research, KAIST, and POSTECH, the
system addresses core challenges: scaling across diverse codebases from C to
Java, achieving high precision while maintaining broad coverage, and producing
semantically correct patches that preserve intended behavior. We detail the
design philosophy, architectural decisions, and implementation strategies
behind ATLANTIS, share lessons learned from pushing the boundaries of automated
security when program analysis meets modern AI, and release artifacts to
support reproducibility and future research.

</details>


### [368] [Enterprise AI Must Enforce Participant-Aware Access Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14608)
*Shashank Shreedhar Bhatt,Tanmay Rajore,Khushboo Aggarwal,Ganesh Ananthanarayanan,Ranveer Chandra,Nishanth Chandran,Suyash Choudhury,Divya Gupta,Emre Kiciman,Sumit Kumar Pandey,Srinath Setty,Rahul Sharma,Teijia Zhao*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper highlights the risks of data leakage in enterprise-deployed large language models (LLMs), particularly when fine-tuned or used with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). It asserts that existing defenses are inadequate and proposes a deterministic, fine-grained access control framework to prevent such risks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper is motivated by the critical security risks associated with deploying fine-tuned LLMs in enterprise settings, especially concerning leakage of confidential data through multi-user interactions and retrieval-based pipelines.

Method: The authors propose a deterministic, fine-grained access control framework explicitly based on ensuring any training, retrieval, or generated content is authorized for all associated users. This methodology builds upon classical access control principles while addressing challenges in AI.

Result: This approach has been implemented in Microsoft's Copilot Tuning product, enabling organizations to securely fine-tune LLMs with their specific enterprise data.

Conclusion: The paper argues that classical access control principles adapted to modern AI workflows can robustly prevent data leakage, making LLM systems more secure in multi-user environments.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in enterprise settings
where they interact with multiple users and are trained or fine-tuned on
sensitive internal data. While fine-tuning enhances performance by
internalizing domain knowledge, it also introduces a critical security risk:
leakage of confidential training data to unauthorized users. These risks are
exacerbated when LLMs are combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
pipelines that dynamically fetch contextual documents at inference time.
  We demonstrate data exfiltration attacks on AI assistants where adversaries
can exploit current fine-tuning and RAG architectures to leak sensitive
information by leveraging the lack of access control enforcement. We show that
existing defenses, including prompt sanitization, output filtering, system
isolation, and training-level privacy mechanisms, are fundamentally
probabilistic and fail to offer robust protection against such attacks.
  We take the position that only a deterministic and rigorous enforcement of
fine-grained access control during both fine-tuning and RAG-based inference can
reliably prevent the leakage of sensitive data to unauthorized recipients.
  We introduce a framework centered on the principle that any content used in
training, retrieval, or generation by an LLM is explicitly authorized for
\emph{all users involved in the interaction}. Our approach offers a simple yet
powerful paradigm shift for building secure multi-user LLM systems that are
grounded in classical access control but adapted to the unique challenges of
modern AI workflows. Our solution has been deployed in Microsoft Copilot
Tuning, a product offering that enables organizations to fine-tune models using
their own enterprise-specific data.

</details>


### [369] [Adversarial Distilled Retrieval-Augmented Guarding Model for Online Malicious Intent Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14622)
*Yihao Guo,Haocheng Bian,Liutong Zhou,Ze Wang,Zhaoyi Zhang,Francois Kawala,Milan Dean,Ian Fischer,Yuantao Peng,Noyan Tokgozoglu,Ivan Barrientos,Riyaaz Shaik,Rachel Li,Chandru Venkataraman,Reza Shifteh Far,Moses Pawar,Venkat Sundaranatha,Michael Xu,Frank Chu*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper proposes ADRAG, a two-stage framework for efficient and robust online malicious intent detection in interactive applications with LLMs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing systems for online malicious intent detection struggle with real-time performance and the handling of diverse and complex user queries.

Method: The ADRAG framework involves a high-capacity teacher model trained on adversarially perturbed and retrieval-augmented inputs, paired with a student model that uses a continually updated knowledge base for real-time query detection.

Result: ADRAG achieves 98.5% of the performance of a larger 7B-parameter model while surpassing GPT-4 and other models in detection accuracy and delivering significantly reduced latency in real-time applications.

Conclusion: ADRAG offers a practical and scalable solution for safe deployment of LLMs in real-time scenarios, combining strong performance with improved efficiency.

Abstract: With the deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) in interactive
applications, online malicious intent detection has become increasingly
critical. However, existing approaches fall short of handling diverse and
complex user queries in real time. To address these challenges, we introduce
ADRAG (Adversarial Distilled Retrieval-Augmented Guard), a two-stage framework
for robust and efficient online malicious intent detection. In the training
stage, a high-capacity teacher model is trained on adversarially perturbed,
retrieval-augmented inputs to learn robust decision boundaries over diverse and
complex user queries. In the inference stage, a distillation scheduler
transfers the teacher's knowledge into a compact student model, with a
continually updated knowledge base collected online. At deployment, the compact
student model leverages top-K similar safety exemplars retrieved from the
online-updated knowledge base to enable both online and real-time malicious
query detection. Evaluations across ten safety benchmarks demonstrate that
ADRAG, with a 149M-parameter model, achieves 98.5% of WildGuard-7B's
performance, surpasses GPT-4 by 3.3% and Llama-Guard-3-8B by 9.5% on
out-of-distribution detection, while simultaneously delivering up to 5.6x lower
latency at 300 queries per second (QPS) in real-time applications.

</details>


### [370] [Early Approaches to Adversarial Fine-Tuning for Prompt Injection Defense: A 2022 Study of GPT-3 and Contemporary Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14271)
*Gustavo Sandoval,Denys Fenchenko,Junyao Chen*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper investigates prompt injection and goal hijacking attacks on large language models (LLMs), proposes a defense using Adversarial Fine-Tuning, and assesses its effectiveness, significantly reducing attack success rates for smaller GPT-3 variants.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper aims to address vulnerabilities in large language models to adversarial attacks like prompt injection and goal hijacking, as these are critical concerns for the secure deployment of AI systems.

Method: The researchers constructed and tested adversarial attacks on various LLMs, proposing Adversarial Fine-Tuning as a novel defense technique to mitigate these vulnerabilities.

Result: Adversarial Fine-Tuning significantly reduced attack success rates to nearly zero for smaller GPT-3 models. However, larger and more flexible models exhibited greater vulnerabilities compared to their smaller counterparts.

Conclusion: While fine-tuning-based defenses showed initial promise, subsequent research revealed their limitations. Still, this early work laid foundational methodologies and insights for advancing prompt injection defense strategies.

Abstract: This paper documents early research conducted in 2022 on defending against
prompt injection attacks in large language models, providing historical context
for the evolution of this critical security domain. This research focuses on
two adversarial attacks against Large Language Models (LLMs): prompt injection
and goal hijacking. We examine how to construct these attacks, test them on
various LLMs, and compare their effectiveness. We propose and evaluate a novel
defense technique called Adversarial Fine-Tuning. Our results show that,
without this defense, the attacks succeeded 31\% of the time on GPT-3 series
models. When using our Adversarial Fine-Tuning approach, attack success rates
were reduced to near zero for smaller GPT-3 variants (Ada, Babbage, Curie),
though we note that subsequent research has revealed limitations of
fine-tuning-based defenses. We also find that more flexible models exhibit
greater vulnerability to these attacks. Consequently, large models such as
GPT-3 Davinci are more vulnerable than smaller models like GPT-2. While the
specific models tested are now superseded, the core methodology and empirical
findings contributed to the foundation of modern prompt injection defense
research, including instruction hierarchy systems and constitutional AI
approaches.

</details>


### [371] [A Simple and Efficient Jailbreak Method Exploiting LLMs' Helpfulness](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14297)
*Xuan Luo,Yue Wang,Zefeng He,Geng Tu,Jing Li,Ruifeng Xu*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper introduces HILL, a jailbreak method that turns harmful requests into learning-style questions, exposing vulnerabilities in LLM safety measures.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To uncover and address vulnerabilities in LLM safety mechanisms by simulating malicious attacks.

Method: A new jailbreak approach called HILL, which transforms harmful requests into learning-style questions using simple hypothetical terms; two new evaluation metrics are also introduced.

Result: HILL achieves high attack success rates across various models, is robust against most defenses, and reveals safety flaws in LLMs.

Conclusion: LLMs face significant challenges balancing safety and helpfulness, as demonstrated by the vulnerabilities exposed by HILL.

Abstract: Safety alignment aims to prevent Large Language Models (LLMs) from responding
to harmful queries. To strengthen safety protections, jailbreak methods are
developed to simulate malicious attacks and uncover vulnerabilities. In this
paper, we introduce HILL (Hiding Intention by Learning from LLMs), a novel
jailbreak approach that systematically transforms imperative harmful requests
into learning-style questions with only straightforward hypotheticality
indicators. Further, we introduce two new metrics to thoroughly evaluate the
utility of jailbreak methods. Experiments on the AdvBench dataset across a wide
range of models demonstrate HILL's strong effectiveness, generalizability, and
harmfulness. It achieves top attack success rates on the majority of models and
across malicious categories while maintaining high efficiency with concise
prompts. Results of various defense methods show the robustness of HILL, with
most defenses having mediocre effects or even increasing the attack success
rates. Moreover, the assessment on our constructed safe prompts reveals
inherent limitations of LLMs' safety mechanisms and flaws in defense methods.
This work exposes significant vulnerabilities of safety measures against
learning-style elicitation, highlighting a critical challenge of balancing
helpfulness and safety alignments.

</details>


### [372] [Threat Modeling for Enhancing Security of IoT Audio Classification Devices under a Secure Protocols Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14657)
*Sergio Benlloch-Lopez,Miquel Viel-Vazquez,Javier Naranjo-Alcazar,Jordi Grau-Haro,Pedro Zuccarello*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper proposes a security framework for IoT devices with microphones, focusing on protecting sensitive data through a layered architecture utilizing TPM, TLS 1.3, encryption methods, and post-quantum resilience.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: With IoT nodes exposing sensitive audio data while operating under resource constraints, the paper addresses the urgent need for a secure system to protect such data.

Method: The approach includes using defense-in-depth architecture, threat modeling, TPM-related measures, post-quantum cryptography, and encryption techniques to ensure security across edge devices, networks, and cloud backends.

Result: A comprehensive protocol and security framework was designed that integrates both hardware and software protections at various stages of data processing, storage, and transmission.

Conclusion: The proposed framework ensures secure communication, storage, and processing of sensitive data in IoT devices using a multi-layered security architecture and hybrid cryptography, and outlines an evaluation plan for its reliability.

Abstract: The rapid proliferation of IoT nodes equipped with microphones and capable of
performing on-device audio classification exposes highly sensitive data while
operating under tight resource constraints. To protect against this, we present
a defence-in-depth architecture comprising a security protocol that treats the
edge device, cellular network and cloud backend as three separate trust
domains, linked by TPM-based remote attestation and mutually authenticated TLS
1.3. A STRIDE-driven threat model and attack-tree analysis guide the design. At
startup, each boot stage is measured into TPM PCRs. The node can only decrypt
its LUKS-sealed partitions after the cloud has verified a TPM quote and
released a one-time unlock key. This ensures that rogue or tampered devices
remain inert. Data in transit is protected by TLS 1.3 and hybridised with Kyber
and Dilithium to provide post-quantum resilience. Meanwhile, end-to-end
encryption and integrity hashes safeguard extracted audio features. Signed,
rollback-protected AI models and tamper-responsive sensors harden firmware and
hardware. Data at rest follows a 3-2-1 strategy comprising a solid-state drive
sealed with LUKS, an offline cold archive encrypted with a hybrid post-quantum
cipher and an encrypted cloud replica. Finally, we set out a plan for
evaluating the physical and logical security of the proposed protocol.

</details>


### [373] [A Multi-Agent LLM Defense Pipeline Against Prompt Injection Attacks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14285)
*S M Asif Hossain,Ruksat Khan Shayoni,Mohd Ruhul Ameen,Akif Islam,M. F. Mridha,Jungpil Shin*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper introduces a multi-agent framework for defending against prompt injection attacks in Large Language Models, achieving 100% mitigation effectiveness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Prompt injection attacks in LLMs undermine system prompts and induce unintended actions, posing serious security risks in deployment.

Method: A multi-agent defense framework is implemented, featuring sequential and hierarchical agent pipelines for detecting and neutralizing prompt injection attacks.

Result: The framework achieved 100% mitigation, reducing Attack Success Rates from 30% (ChatGLM) and 20% (Llama2) to 0% across 400 attack instances.

Conclusion: The multi-agent framework proves robust against various attack categories, ensuring security while preserving functionality for legitimate usage.

Abstract: Prompt injection attacks represent a major vulnerability in Large Language
Model (LLM) deployments, where malicious instructions embedded in user inputs
can override system prompts and induce unintended behaviors. This paper
presents a novel multi-agent defense framework that employs specialized LLM
agents in coordinated pipelines to detect and neutralize prompt injection
attacks in real-time. We evaluate our approach using two distinct
architectures: a sequential chain-of-agents pipeline and a hierarchical
coordinator-based system. Our comprehensive evaluation on 55 unique prompt
injection attacks, grouped into 8 categories and totaling 400 attack instances
across two LLM platforms (ChatGLM and Llama2), demonstrates significant
security improvements. Without defense mechanisms, baseline Attack Success
Rates (ASR) reached 30% for ChatGLM and 20% for Llama2. Our multi-agent
pipeline achieved 100% mitigation, reducing ASR to 0% across all tested
scenarios. The framework demonstrates robustness across multiple attack
categories including direct overrides, code execution attempts, data
exfiltration, and obfuscation techniques, while maintaining system
functionality for legitimate queries.

</details>


### [374] [Blockchain-Enabled Explainable AI for Trusted Healthcare Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14987)
*Md Talha Mohsin*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: This paper presents BXHF, a framework combining blockchain and Explainable AI to enhance secure data exchange and transparent clinical decision-making in healthcare.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the dual challenges of safe data exchange and comprehensible AI-driven decision-making in healthcare networks.

Method: BXHF integrates blockchain for secure and immutable patient records, and XAI for transparent model predictions within a unified optimization pipeline and hybrid edge-cloud architecture.

Result: BXHF demonstrated effectiveness in use cases like cross-border research, rare disease detection, and high-risk intervention decision-making.

Conclusion: BXHF enhances credibility, transparency, and compliance in AI-driven healthcare, paving the way for safer clinical decisions.

Abstract: This paper introduces a Blockchain-Integrated Explainable AI Framework (BXHF)
for healthcare systems to tackle two essential challenges confronting health
information networks: safe data exchange and comprehensible AI-driven clinical
decision-making. Our architecture incorporates blockchain, ensuring patient
records are immutable, auditable, and tamper-proof, alongside Explainable AI
(XAI) methodologies that yield transparent and clinically relevant model
predictions. By incorporating security assurances and interpretability
requirements into a unified optimization pipeline, BXHF ensures both data-level
trust (by verified and encrypted record sharing) and decision-level trust (with
auditable and clinically aligned explanations). Its hybrid edge-cloud
architecture allows for federated computation across different institutions,
enabling collaborative analytics while protecting patient privacy. We
demonstrate the framework's applicability through use cases such as
cross-border clinical research networks, uncommon illness detection and
high-risk intervention decision support. By ensuring transparency,
auditability, and regulatory compliance, BXHF improves the credibility, uptake,
and effectiveness of AI in healthcare, laying the groundwork for safer and more
reliable clinical decision-making.

</details>


### [375] [Watermarking and Anomaly Detection in Machine Learning Models for LORA RF Fingerprinting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.15170)
*Aarushi Mahajan,Wayne Burleson*

Main category: cs.CR

TL;DR: The paper introduces a robust Radio Frequency Fingerprint Identification (RFFI) system that combines watermarking and anomaly detection to improve authentication accuracy and security.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address vulnerabilities in current RFFI systems, such as susceptibility to copying, tampering, and evasion, and improve the robustness and verifiability of wireless device authentication.

Method: The system employs a ResNet-34 on log-Mel spectrograms, embedding three types of watermarks—simple, adversarially robust, and hidden gradient/weight signature—and uses a convolutional Variational Autoencoder (VAE) with KL warm-up and free-bits for anomaly detection.

Result: Achieved 94.6% accuracy in authentication, 98% success rate for watermarking, and 0.94 AUROC on the LoRa dataset.

Conclusion: The proposed system effectively enhances the security and reliability of RFFI by integrating robust ownership proof and tamper-resistant anomaly detection mechanisms.

Abstract: Radio frequency fingerprint identification (RFFI) distinguishes wireless
devices by the small variations in their analog circuits, avoiding heavy
cryptographic authentication. While deep learning on spectrograms improves
accuracy, models remain vulnerable to copying, tampering, and evasion. We
present a stronger RFFI system combining watermarking for ownership proof and
anomaly detection for spotting suspicious inputs. Using a ResNet-34 on log-Mel
spectrograms, we embed three watermarks: a simple trigger, an adversarially
trained trigger robust to noise and filtering, and a hidden gradient/weight
signature. A convolutional Variational Autoencoders (VAE) with Kullback-Leibler
(KL) warm-up and free-bits flags off-distribution queries. On the LoRa dataset,
our system achieves 94.6% accuracy, 98% watermark success, and 0.94 AUROC,
offering verifiable, tamper-resistant authentication.

</details>

### [376] [Scaling Hybrid Quantum-HPC Applications with the Quantum Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14470)
*Srikar Chundury,Amir Shehata,Seongmin Kim,Muralikrishnan Gopalakrishnan Meena,Chao Lu,Kalyana Gottiparthi,Eduardo Antonio Coello Perez,Frank Mueller,In-Saeng Suh*

Main category: quant-ph

TL;DR: The study enhances the Quantum Framework (QFw) to integrate various quantum simulators and a cloud-based backend to support hybrid quantum-HPC workflows, showing backend-specific strengths and encouraging scalable Q-HPC ecosystems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Hybrid quantum-HPC workflows are pivotal for running quantum applications effectively on current NISQ devices. However, the variability in simulator performance based on circuit structure necessitates a flexible execution model that allows fair benchmarking and optimized platform usage.

Method: The Quantum Framework (QFw) was extended to support multiple local and cloud-based quantum backends like Qiskit Aer, NWQ-Sim, QTensor, TN-QVM, and IonQ through a unified API. Various workloads, both non-variational and variational, were executed to showcase backend-specific strengths.

Result: The research identified that Qiskit Aer excels in large Ising models, while NWQ-Sim is better suited for tasks requiring large-scale entanglement and distributed computation. It also shows the advantages of using workload-specific backends for optimization.

Conclusion: This simulator-agnostic, HPC-aware orchestration approach advances scalable, reproducible, and portable Q-HPC ecosystems. It aids in identifying quantum advantage opportunities and accelerates progress in demonstrating quantum advantage.

Abstract: Hybrid quantum-high performance computing (Q-HPC) workflows are emerging as a
key strategy for running quantum applications at scale in current noisy
intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices. These workflows must operate
seamlessly across diverse simulators and hardware backends since no single
simulator offers the best performance for every circuit type. Simulation
efficiency depends strongly on circuit structure, entanglement, and depth,
making a flexible and backend-agnostic execution model essential for fair
benchmarking, informed platform selection, and ultimately the identification of
quantum advantage opportunities. In this work, we extend the Quantum Framework
(QFw), a modular and HPC-aware orchestration layer, to integrate multiple local
backends (Qiskit Aer, NWQ-Sim, QTensor, and TN-QVM) and a cloud-based quantum
backend (IonQ) under a unified interface. Using this integration, we execute a
number of non-variational as well as variational workloads. The results
highlight workload-specific backend advantages: while Qiskit Aer's matrix
product state excels for large Ising models, NWQ-Sim not only leads on
large-scale entanglement and Hamiltonian but also shows the benefits of
concurrent subproblem execution in a distributed manner for optimization
problems. These findings demonstrate that simulator-agnostic, HPC-aware
orchestration is a practical path toward scalable, reproducible, and portable
Q-HPC ecosystems, thereby accelerating progress toward demonstrating quantum
advantage.

</details>


### [377] [Efficiently learning depth-3 circuits via quantum agnostic boosting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.14461)
*Srinivasan Arunachalam,Arkopal Dutt,Alexandru Gheorghiu,Michael de Oliveira*

Main category: quant-ph

TL;DR: This paper explores quantum agnostic learning for phase states tied to specific classical function classes using agnostic learning protocols and introduces quantum boosting for stronger learner development.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The paper aims to advance quantum agnostic learning to efficiently learn complex structures like depth-3 circuits using quantum examples, addressing challenges from classical PAC learning theory.

Method: Developed quantum agnostic learning protocols and a boosting mechanism that upgrades weak agnostic learners to strong learners for better fidelity with unknown states.

Result: Achieved near-polynomial time learning protocols for depth-3 circuits in the quantum PAC model, significantly advancing computational learning possibilities beyond classical approaches.

Conclusion: The paper provides a breakthrough in learning phase states and depth-3 circuits using quantum methods, offering a paradigm shift in computational learning theory with quantum examples.

Abstract: We initiate the study of quantum agnostic learning of phase states with
